div1.p: Truby reviews Chapter 3 of Standlee's manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Mary Standlee, May 26, 1951 [Enclosed in 06504036]
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
May 26, 1951
Mrs. Mary W. Standlee
The Library
Walter Reed Army Hospital
The Army Medical Center
Washington 12, D. C.
Dear Mrs. Standlee:
div1.p:
In reviewing your manuscript, Chapter 3, I find that I will have to write it all
out in long hand and then later have it typed.

To save myself work, I am referring to my book, “Memoirs of Walter Reed - The
Yellow Fever Episode”, with the page numbers in brackets and I think you will
find it easy from the references to my book to understand where things fit itn.
Your Page 37-

First paragraph “By early spring of 1900...” should be 1899. See my book,
page 40, note 4, April 29, 1899. Reed and Carroll were already convinced that
Sanarelli's organism was not the cause of yellow fever. Dr. Hammeter's refer-
ence, No. 8, probably came from Reed and Carroll's article in the Medical News
of April 29. (Note 4). Additional work on blood cultures from new cases of
yellow fever were necessary to compatre with Wasdin and Geddings' work on
similar cases of yellow fever. (Pg. 87.)
Page 38-

Last paragraph. The outbreak of yellow fever at Mariano (Pg. 78) was
purely incidental and had no bearing on the orders for the Reed Board. The
first case of yellow fever there occurred on May 19 and the orders for the
Board were issued May 23rd from Washington so that the epidemic had just started.
During March and April, 1900, Reed lived with us at the Hospital, Columbia Bks.
Then he went direct to Washington and I am sure he requested orders to continue
work on the etiology of yellow fever. (Pg. 76.)

Dr. Welch was probably consulted about Dr. Lazear's qualifications for
Reed had become well acquainted with him and his work in the laboratory at
Columbia Bks. during March and April. (See last paragraph, Pg. 75; also Page 76.)
As Reed had already concluded that our Hospital was the place to study yellow
fever and that Lazear would be helpful to him in his laboratory work, I am sure
that my observations are more nearly correct than those of writers who are only
guessing. There is no factual confirmation of the Reed-Welch discussion as far
as I know.
Page 39-

Re your Note 13b, I have never seen or heard of any verbal or written
discussions between Dr. Welch and Gen. Sternberg about the Reed Board. Neither
of these distinguished men could give Reed much information on entomology,
especially on mosquito work, but Reed had already made contact with Dr. L. O.
Howard, the entomologist of the Department of Agriculture in Washington.
(Pgs. 141-143 and 194-195.)

- 2 -
Mrs. Mary W. Standlee.
Page 39-

Lazear reported for duty at the Columbia Barracks Hospital as the result of
my request that a bacteriologist be assigned to duty in our laboratory. (Pgs. 60-
61.) Lazear had, I think, requested duty as a Contract Surgeon in some Army
laboratory and when his application arrived in the SGO, Mr. Jones, the Chief
Clerk, probably had him sent to Cuba to meet our request. This lest sentence
is not factual but my memory indicates that Lazear gave me that information.
There is nothing that I know of indicating that Dr. Welch had anything to do
with the assignment of Lazear as described above.

Lazear and Reed first met in March, 1900 at the Hospital, Columbia Bks., Cuba.
(Pg. 75) Reed therefore wanted him on the Yellow Fever Board and also wanted
Agramonte who was an immune. (Pg. 76) Reed and Carroll returned to Cuba,
June 25, 1900. (Pg. 77) I think the words very positive should be substituted
for “conclusive”.
Page 39-

Instead of “Dr. Reed had to return....” I would change that sentence to
read, as follows: “Major Reed was ordered...”. In those days, many people in
the Service did not like to give doctors their military title but it was always
used in military orders. While Dr. Carroll was the senior Board member present
during Reed's absence, both he and Lazear had their work prescribed for them by
Maj. Reed and there was practically no administrative work required. Sgt. Neate
was really the man who had cultures and mosquitoes to look after and he got his
instructions on cultures from Carroll. Lazear had already taught him how to
breed, feed, and care for mosquitoes and they all worked in harmony doing their
special duties. Carroll was completely wrapped up with his intestinal flora job
and I never saw him do anything else until after he recovered from yellow fever.
Page 39-

As the experiments had scarcely begun when Reed was as Pinar del Rio, I
doubt if he thought of fomites at all. It was Gorgas who continued to disinfect
homes in Havana after the Board's reports were published. (Pgs. 184-185.)

“Urged by the younger members of the Board”. No doubt Lazear did urge Reed to
begin testing Finlay's theory, but Carroll and Agramonte probably did not.
Lazear was not an entomologist but was much interested and had done much work
in studying mosquitoes. Reed felt that the Board's work in studying Sanarelli's
theory, as Wasdin and Geddings had done on fresh cases of yellow fever, must be
completed first. (See Pg. 87.) Then they could take up the mosquito theory.
However, he and Lazear did start the breeding of mosquitoes and I saw then at
✗ this work about the middle of July, 1900. (Pgs. 90-93 and 103-104.) Work on
the Sanarelli theory was then concluded and Reed left for Washington on August 2
to finish the typhoid fever report and Lazear was given the go-ahead signal with
infected mosquitoes. (Pgs. 101-104.)
Page 40-

Lazear was not immune. If Hammeter credits Dr. Welch as saying that Carroll
was “the real hero”, I think he meant that because he was the first case of
experimental yellow fever, and not the “accurate and flawless leader in the work”.
Hammeter's statement should not be accepted as a fact unless it can be shown when,
See p 233 Sen. Doc. last par. Kean wrote this himself
and it shows that Finlay was visited early after arrival
of Reed in Cuba on June 25, 1900
- 3 -
Mrs. Mary W. Standlee
where, and to whom it was made. I think Dr. Welch's letter to the Secretary of
War should be copied in full in your story to counteract anything so completely
false. I know - for I was there; and further, my book tells why Carroll was
unable to be of any help to Reed or Lazear during his illness and long convalescence.
For the Welch statement, see Senate Document 822, 1911, Page 20. Right here,
you should also quote Gen. Leonard Wood's statement in full. (Also in Senate
Document 822, 1911, Page 20.)

I am much perturbed by your failure to bring out the splendid things said about
Reed, especially in that wonderful book, Senate Document 822, 1911, prepared
by Gen. Kean. He wrote most of the text not long after the work in Cuba so that
is reliable. Why not give both sides of the controversy?

I also wish to state that since about 1938, Gen. Kean, Dr. Hench and I have been
constantly working on this yellow fever episode and trying to help Dr. Hench in
getting factual data on things in my book which were based on my memory and those
of doctors and enlisted men who were in Cuba with me. So far I think that
nothing of importance has been found wrong. I suggest that you follow
Dr. Hench's advice carefully. Hammeter was no authority on the subject and
I expect that there are others in Washington who are in the same category.
Much of your story about the work done fifty years ago is from the memory of
not
people who were not in Cuba and therefore it is hearsay. In this yellow fever
episode, we must be factual and demand facts before we print them.

Unless you can finally summarize all the conflicting statements and give Reed
the credit of being the master mind in the Board's work, as shown by the
statements of the Secretary of War, Dr. Welch, General Leonard Wood, Gens.
Sternberg, McCaw, Kean and others in Senate Document 822, 1911, I would not
like to see this Chapter published in connection with a history of the
Walter Reed Army Hospital - the great memorial to Walter Reed.

Professor Welch was a good friend of mine and when he came to see Gen. Ireland,
which was often, he had to pass through my office (SGO Executive Officer) and
often, especially when the Surgeon General was away, he talked with me about
Reed's work and my experiences in Cuba. He was truly a great medical man and
when he stated “I am in a position to know that the credit for the original
ideas embodied in this work (yellow fever experiments) belongs wholly to
Maj. Reed”, it seems to me Dr. Hammeter's statement unsupported by documentary
facts re the statement has no place in your history; likewise, when Gen. Leonard
Wood, who, as Governor General of Cuba, gave Reed so much time and assistance
says: “His work was the originating, directing, and controlling mind in this
work, and the others were assistants only”. I was there and I know these
statements are true.
AET

I wrote the above in longhand two days ago but had to stop as I was completely
worn out by my efforts to hurry up as you requested. I tried to save myself
by giving page references from my book and leaving the writing for you. However,
I exploded as you see for on this subject I get too excited and upset for my own
good. I have left things just as they were for, on my doctor's advice, it is
time to stop all work of this kind for some time. On his advice and also on
Mrs. Truby's insistence, I am therefore compelled, but with sincere regret, to
return your manuscript without further review by me. Of course you will be
- 4 -
Mrs. Mary W. Standlee.
shocked by this turn of events but it can't be helped.
Don't blame yourself,
it could not have been
prevented.
AET

I have been most interested in Gen. Love's comments and of all the retired
officers of the Corps in Washington, you can not, I think, find a more
competent and honest advisor on this yellow fever episode.

The Senate Document 822, 1911 has long been “my bible” in this work. It was
thrown together hurriedly by our lamented friend, Gen. Kean, so there were
many errors but by correspondence I know the correct answer to most of them.
I hope you will refer to it more frequently.

One last suggestion which you may not like. Why try to solve these controversies
in your story when we know that Dr. Hench has made and continues to make the
most factual and complete investigation on the whole subject, and that he will
publish it as soon as he possibly can? No one can or even will try to do
what he has done on this subject. His will be the last word

If at any time there is any question that I can answer, don't hesitate to call
on me. However, I must not undertake any long and tedious work.

closer.seg:
P.S. Yours of the 22nd just came and I think that fills the bill splendidly.
I have made a few changes in pencil on it (mms) which you can change if it is
OK. with you
